user.name: React

full_text: @marvinhagemeist @rauchg @khpatel4991 @_developit @timneutkens With Server Components, the benefit of Concurrent Mode is that we can start rendering Client components in memory *as they stream in* instead of waiting for the whole fetch to finish. So we don’t waste time and can put the CPU to work while we wait for Network anyway.

user.name: React

full_text: @marvinhagemeist @rauchg @khpatel4991 @_developit @timneutkens Also, once you start using declarative loading states (thanks to Suspense), you’ll notice that hiding existing content on refetches leads to poor UX, but providing no indication is also bad. This is also something that Concurrent Mode solves out of the box.

full_text: @marvinhagemeist @rauchg @khpatel4991 @_developit @timneutkens As an example of how it can benefit Next, Concurrent Mode supports progressive hydration. It lets us begin hydrating and make parts interactive before all the code loads. Unlike in the past, we don’t blow away server HTML for the parts that are loading. And it’s non-blocking.
